awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE Incubator: Building an interdisciplinary regional network to expose under-represented students to biological research in its community context
awd_abstract_narration:
Research has shown that under-served students typically have few opportunities to engage in high-impact research activities and that first-generation college students want their learning to be connected to their home communities. When educators attempt to improve upon undergraduate research opportunities they frequently focus on placing only select students in one-on-one faculty mentored research and fail to link the research to the students’ daily lives. All students should have an opportunity to participate in research in ways that make explicit connections between the content, process, and application of research, or they risk not being able to see the relevance of biological science to their own lives. This RNC-UBE incubator network will remove these barriers by developing course-based opportunities for students to engage with real-life data sets provided by regional organizations whose work is informed by biological research. Therefore, all students taking introductory biology courses will build research skills within a socially meaningful and applied community context.  Furthermore, by participating in the course-based research modules developed by this regional network, students will gain a greater understanding of job market diversity as it pertains to skills gained during biological research.  

This network brings together educators from different universities, community colleges, as well as research scientists from an urban health department, a nationally recognized primate research center, and a major regional river authority tasked with ecological stewardship. The network members will participate in workshops designed to develop course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) which will be implemented as pilot modules in introductory biology courses. Workshops will also identify alignment of modules with core curriculum learning objectives, community partner needs, and potential barriers to implementation. During the pilot CURE modules students will collect and analyze data sets on the prevalence and disparities of heritable genetic disorders, diabetes, cancer or environmental threats to the community, many of which disproportionately burden the network’s predominately Hispanic population.  This RCN-UBE Incubator will increase collaborative research among students, academia, industry, and community civic services and thus enhance the diversity of the future STEM workforce. Students participating in the modules will develop skills in science communication by sharing their results with public groups, family members and network representatives. The impact of the network will extend beyond students and faculty to include members of the community who might otherwise have limited exposure to scientific research, thereby nurturing positive attitudes towards biological research and increased engagement and support of family members with their children’s STEM education. 
This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources (EHR), Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/). This project is also supported by the NSF HSI and IUSE:EHR programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The RCN-UBE incubator project aimed to develop Course-Based Undergraduate Research (CURE) opportunities with the goal of helping students build research skills within a socially meaningful and applied community context. These opportunities would allow students in introductory biology courses to engage with real-life datasets provided by regional organizations involved in biological research. 

Our network brought together representatives from diverse entities, including an urban health department, a primate research center, a biomedical research institute, a regional river authority focused on ecological stewardship, a city water system, a parks and recreation department, a parks and wildlife entity, and four Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs). Through seven workshops with network partners, we identified eight potential CUREs. We successfully developed and implemented two during the incubator period.

The most viable CUREs identified for large first-year biology courses involved the analysis of large datasets provided by community research partners. These datasets had gone unanalyzed largely due to resource constraints by the agencies. While students didn't generate the data, analyzing it provided them with valuable quantitative and analytic skills, while also providing value to the community partners. We achieved our RCN-UBE mission of providing opportunities for all students in introductory biology courses to develop research skills within a socially meaningful and applied community context.

Two CUREs were implemented in first-year General Biology I and II courses, engaging about 90 students. In General Biology I, students delved into "Entry and preliminary analysis of trail pedestrian and bike count data across San Antonio Parks and Recreation locations," linking the content to anabolic and catabolic metabolic pathways and their relationship to physical activity. In General Biology II, the focus shifted to "Entry and preliminary analysis of city-wide mosquito surveillance data with the City of San Antonio Metropolitan Health District," connecting to concepts of community and population ecology. Both CUREs involved students formulating hypotheses and predictions, training in basic Excel spreadsheet management, graph creation, and culminating in oral presentations.

A post-CURE survey showed positive student perceptions of CURE integration. Beyond the primary goal of creating and fine-tuning dataset CUREs, we also conducted a survey comparing students who participated in CUREs with those who did not. Participants demonstrated a significantly stronger belief in their ability to contribute to science in their community. They were also more inclined to share their new-found biological knowledge with friends and family. This suggests that the CURE design, employing community-based datasets, was not only meaningful within the academic context but also reached a broader audience.

Further, three out of approximately 60 students who participated in the mosquito survey CURE sought more intensive undergraduate research experiences with faculty, highlighting the transformative impact of this experience on first-year students. This increased confidence and interest in biology research underscores the broader impact of the initiative.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: This RCN-UBE incubator project sought to address 1) the lack of opportunities that many students have to engage in high-impact research activities, 2) the disconnect between scientific content and scientific process in undergraduate biology, and 3) the failure to link research to students’ daily lives.  To do this, we created a network of educators from different universities, community colleges, and research scientists from community-based entities to develop course-based opportunities for students to engage with real-life data sets provided by these community organizations whose work is informed by biological research. In so doing, we provided all students taking introductory biology courses with an opportunity to build research skills within a socially meaningful and applied community context. To ensure that the contexts of students’ lives be taken into consideration, we sought cross-disciplinary research opportunities at the intersection of biology, applied industry and civic institutions that rely on science to provide direct service to the community (e.g., epidemiology and public health promotion, water quality and remediation, ecology/land management).

BROADER IMPACTS: A&M-SA is an HSI and the Alamo Community Colleges District includes many HSIs and the only Historically Black community college in the country. This RCN-UBE Incubator network resulted in much–needed open educational resources and protocols for use in Community Colleges, HSIs, and broader educational settings, including those with a large proportion of low-income, first-generation and minority students. The project therefore nurtures the diversity of the future STEM workforce. This Incubator has increased partnerships between academia, industry, city services and community organizations in South Texas. The impact of the network has also extended beyond students and faculty to include members of the community who might otherwise have limited exposure to scientific research, thereby nurturing positive attitudes towards biology and increased engagement and support of family members with their children’s education.
